title: Manitoba man says province won't cover his $118,000 medical bill from U.S.

organizations.name: the canadian press related stories manitoba

text:
Manitoba man says province won't cover his $118,000 medical bill from U.S. CTVNews.ca Staff Published Thursday, February 2, 2017 9:24PM EST 
A Manitoba man says he isn’t getting any financial help from the province after he was slapped with a medical bill for $118,000 for a life-saving procedure in the U.S. 
Robin Milne, 60, lives a few kilometres north of the American border in Sprague, Man. When he suffered a heart attack last October, he rushed to the closest hospital in Roseau, Minnesota, where Manitobans have health coverage through a U.S.-Canadian deal. 
A doctor then told Milne to get a heart stent at another hospital in North Dakota, a state where Manitobans are not automatically covered. The decision came after Milne says he waited 90 minutes for an air transfer to a Winnipeg hospital. 
He later received the whopping medical bill. Milne says he’d need to remortgage his house or dip into retirement savings to cover the six-figure expense. 
Milne has spoken out about his story, but he says the province still won’t help him with the payment. 
“Pretty devastated by that news. I really felt that they would be a lot more compassionate than that,” he told CTV Winnipeg. “Why they’re playing hardball … I just don’t know.” 
A spokesperson for the province told CTV Winnipeg that they could not speak to the details of a specific case. The province says that, by law, Health Minister Kelvin Goertzen does not have the authority to order Milne’s bill to be covered. 
"Additional clarity about eligibility of coverage and services is needed for both residents of Manitoba and the service providers in the United States," Goertzen said in an earlier statement on the case. 
Manitoba’s NDP health critic says the minister should do more to help Milne. 
“He should look at this particular case, revisit it and do the right thing: step up and make sure that he pays this bill for this patient,” said MPP Matt Wiebe. 
Milne says he understands that there was a “breakdown” during his case, but that he was forced to make a life-or-death decision under pressure from a U.S. medical expert. He added that he’s upset with the way elected officials have handled the problem. 
“When we elect these people to represent us and the response that we get from them is so unkind, I just don’t know.” 
With a report from CTV Winnipeg and The Canadian Press Related Stories Manitoba man slapped with $118,000 bill after emergency room transfer in U.S. Photos Robin Milne, 60, says he isn't getting help from the Manitoba government for a $118,000 medical bill he received after getting a procedure done in North Dakota.
